slides.body:
At Los Alamos and elsewhere, the first computers were humans who did calculations by hand, sometimes with the help of a desktop calculator.

Most of these human computers were women. Although not always recognized, their word propelled science and engineering forward for decades.
slides.alt: Women calculating at desks in NASA 1967

slides.body:
when electronic computers were introduced, women were often the first programmers and computer operators.

Their pioneering application of the new machines to scientific and national security challenges mad possible the rapid technical advances in the years that followed.

slides.body:
The legacy of women building the future through computing continues at Los Alamos today.

Discover more about the legacy and ongoing contributions of women in computing at Los Alamos.

tubie.body: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Dolor morbi non arcu risus quis varius quam quisque. Tellus in metus vulputate eu scelerisque felis imperdiet.

slides.body: The first computers at Los Alamos were mostly women from the town's civilian community. Professional computers from the Woman's Army Corps (WACs) soon grew the ranks of human computers at the Lab to about twenty. Without their skilled and tireless computing work, Los Alamos' wartime mission would not have succeeded.

tubie.body: The term "computer" was first used over 400 years ago. A "computer" was a person who did calculations by hand.

slides.body:
After World War II, women from the Lab's hand-computing group became the world's first programmers (then called "coders").

Human computers had the skills needed to translate complex problems into the software "code" that an electronic computer could understand. Women with degrees in science and mathematics came to Los Alamos from all over the United States to meet the Lab's urgent Cold War need for computing expertise.

tubie.body: Human computers often did a calculation twice to check for errors.

slides.body:
The 1970's brought many changes to Los Alamos. The Cray-1 revolutionized supercomputer performance and computer networking made the lab a smaller (and faster) place.

Women stepped up to a growing number of roles in computing - from networking technicians to group leaders - to make sure Los Alamos continued to set the pace in supercomputer technology and scientific research.

tubie.body: Electronic computers didn't replace human computers right away. Human computers were still better than early electronic computers at some important tasks.

slides.body: Stockpile Stewardship gave new importance to supercomputer simulations at Los Alamos in the 1990s. Women played key roles in researching and evaluating new technologies (such as cluster computing) that would guide Los Alamos into the twenty-first century of supercomputing, and without the need for live weapons testing.

Today, women are security experts protecting Los Alamos computer networks; they are computer scientists designing programs to combat climate change; they are systems analysts who keep the lab's supercomputers working to serve the national interest; they experts who make Los Alamos make a difference.
 Much has changed at Los Alamos since human computers powered the Manhattan Project, but the legacy of women building the future through computing continues.

inTheirWordsData.body: Hear more about the groundbreaking discoveries and contributions women make at Los Alamos, in their own words.

timelineData.title: Explore the timeline
timelineData.subtitle:
Legacy of Women in 
 Los Alamos Computing

lines.body: The term "computer" was first used over 400 years ago. A "computer" was a person who did calculations by hand.
Human computers often did a calculation twice to check for errors.
Electronic computers didn't replace human computers right away. Human computers were still better than early electronic computers at some important tasks.
Los Alamos employed a group of human computers until 1955.
Many of the first computer programmers at Los Alamos were women who started out as human computers.
Most of the MANIAC computer's operators were women. They knew the computer so well, they could hear a program bug by listening to the sounds the MANIAC made.
Before the term "programmer" was coined in the late 1950s, the people who wrote computer software were called "coders."
During the Manhattan Project, Naomi Livesay and Eleanor Ewing were the mathematicians who managed the IBM punched-card calculating machines at Los Alamos.
Human computers and IBM punched-card calculating machines worked together on the simulations needed to complete the Trinity "Gadget."
In the 1950s, women came to Los Alamos from many parts of the US to work on the MANIAC, one of the few computers in the world at the time.
Los Alamos programmer Mary Tsingou Menzel wrote the first scientific experiment conducted entirely on a computer, called the Fermi-Pasta-Ulam-Tsingou Problem.
Klara von Neumann wrote some of the first programs for the MANIAC computer.
Los Alamos wrote the first large program for an electronic computer. It took up one-million punched cards!
The only patents issued for the Cray-1 computer were for its cooling system.
"Debugging" originally referred to removing insects from mechanical equipment. It was later applied to removing errors from computer software.
